message: What are you doing to migrate your carefully curated math posts to a different storage medium?
I haven't decided where to put it yet,

, but it's going to be a self-hosted blog. I'd love to use my own publishing engine, but since there are a few unresolved issues with it, I might opt for a static site generator instead. An ostatus compatible commenting engine would be nice. Maybe I find a way to embed mastodon for this...

I see no other alternative than a self-hosted blog, because I don't want to go through this again on another platform like Mastodon.  I chose Google because I thought they wanted to keep G+ for effective altruistic reasons:

I was slow to realize that they are now a public company that is profit driven like everyone else.  G+ was cheap to maintain, but the liability costs of not having timely security patches was becoming too risky for the bean counters for a product that generated zero income.
I rarely get comments that aren't spam, so having a commenting engine isn't that important to me.  Monetizing it wouldn't work since all my content has external copyrights.
My goal of blogging publicly was to learn (i.e. teach myself) math and science while promoting scientific literacy and global numeracy
For now, my plan is to migrate everything to dropbox after my "go dark"(go dead?) date of 31Dec2018...Not sure I will be able to pay the costs of a static site for very long if I migrated to one.

One option I've been considering is Hubzilla, because it features "cloning" across Hubzilla nodes. So, I can install Hubzilla on my laptop, as well as one of my Azure Ubuntu VMs, and "clone" my blog across them - in addition to a more mainstream Hubzilla node.

That way, I'd be able to post/comment/etc on my laptop, even when not connected to the internet. After connecting to the internet, my posts/comments/likes/etc would get whooshed to the other clones and Hubzilla/diaspora/Mastodon/etc.

Hubzilla is one of the things that is part of both "the Federation" (diaspora etc) and "the Fediverse (Mastodon etc). So, on Hubzilla I'd see comments from both diaspora and Mastodon users, but diaspora users wouldn't see Mastodon user comments (and vice versa).

The thing about Hubzilla is that it's UI isn't as easy as the others. I think I can live with the learning curve for the sake of the benefits. I feel like I'd use Hubzilla more like a blogging platform which happens to have comments. For most of the way I use G+, I feel like pluspora (a diaspora pod) is a better fit. So I'm keeping my pluspora account even if I use Hubzilla for my main blog.
I seem to follow similar motivations,

, but I do enjoy discussions a lot. So I will certainly need to find ways to accomodate an audience, and means to stay connected to mathematicians. I was surprised to find that social media is so difficult for authors, some platforms appearing downright hostile towards pro bono authors.
However, I'm looking forward to make something out of the wider spectrum of expression that comes with self-hosting.
I should take a closer look at Hubzilla,
. I have to say that I'm quite happy to see ostatus happen. I have clearly not spent enough time to appreciate its potential.

I tried mastodon once when I first saw you mentioning it but it didn't feel "user-friendly"  enough. Also somewhat confusing... Now that this is closing I may feel more compelled enough to give it another try...

I'd say it's not so much an alternative formulation of mechanics, but more of a replacement for the Euler–Lagrange equation,
I have to admit I haven't stared at Gauss's principle for very long, (I bet I will), but he idea feels eerily familiar. I wonder how it relates to symplectic geometry.

It doesn't look critical to me. All these fancy formulations are "essentially" applications of extremal principles...

SYMPLECTIC GEOMETRY is the ultimate generalization of Hamiltonian mechanics! The basic idea of Hamiltonian mechanics is to write down an expression (called Hamiltonian) for a conserved quantity (like energy) as depending on an unknown function p(t) (e.g. position), and one related to its first derivative q(t) (say, momentum). You then demand that the Hamiltonian is stationary, that it doesn't change, which is cleverly formalized by setting its derivative to zero, and solve for p!
This is part 8 of a series on symplectic geometry I have started over here on mastodon:
I have wondered about this curious subject for a very long time, but only recently, when I stumbled into Nöther's theorem again, did I realize that I had enough background to get going!

My latest ventures on covariant symplectic formalism used to explore the structure of various cohomologous Einstein-Cartan Lagrangians. In need of tying together some of ideas. Not sure how pedagogical it is, that was the idea with hit really as not much original thought.
The functional derivative of the boundary term from these

Lagrangians is the symplectic potential that results from performing the ’integration by parts’ in the Variational Principle. This is what is defined as a quasi-local Noether charge and is used to define distinct energy-momentums for each of the Lagrangians.

The Noether charges arise from variations of both the metric (co-frame) and/or affine (connection) variables of the theory and their surface ”charge densities” on the boundary will need to be fixed differently (as per Dirichelet or Neumann) in order to generate deterministic solutions from the equations of motion.

Applying Noether’s theorem using a spinor valued symplectic formalism I also studied the gauge freedom afforded to the contact one form for a chiral Rarita-Schwinger Lagrangian relating the associated Noether symmetries impliclitly to the on-shell satisfaction of Einstein’s Vacuum equations.

Locating the Amplituhedron, decompositions and projections
– So, what is the positive region of a Grassmannian, say Gr(2,4)? Remember, any element of this Grassmannian can be written as a matrix:

Each row is a direction in the containing R^4. Let's fix that plane: what can we do to these vectors x, y such that the subspace span(x,y) stays the same? We can rotate one vector towards the other, and when they point into the same direction the space collapses by one dimension. It's even better to think about more than two vectors, the way we were looking at it works equally well with three fingers: our space also degenerates whenever we pass a finger between two others. Try four or more, it's not hard at all! We start in convex position, there's a plane spanned by every pair of fingers.

In high enough dimension we'd be looking at (k-1)-hyperplanes, but let's better call these planes edges: After all, we are dealing with one vector at a time, so the projective principle should hold and we can intersect our lines with a sphere to make all vectors have unit length and appear as vertices. Well, not really lines with a sphere, but rays with that cross-capped half sphere I mentioned last time. However, by restricting to the positive quadrant/octant/2^n-tant we can safely ignore this global topological pecularity.

So, our fingertips are cyclically ordered along a planar convex k-gon. Between them we have (k-1)-hyperplanes represented as lines, giving a complete graph. If k is large enough we also get (k-2)-hyperplanes selecting three vertices, and so on for every codimension space. Indeed, the positive region has facets in each codimension k-j but let's delay that thought. To exchange two adjacent fingers, one vertex has to cross the lines emanating from the other. We might have to flip some sign whenever that happens...

What are we doing? Hm, we have defined the inside of a particular point P in our Grassmannian using a positive representation. To get a full basis for R^n we would need another n-k vectors for which we have the same kind of freedom. All this keeps the subspace, our point P in the Grassmannian, fixed!
So... we've just worked out a quotient construction to describe Grassmannians!

O(n) is the orthogonal group, O(k) corresponds to all ways to represent a fixed R^k and O(n-k) is the just same for the space outside. But let's stick to the positive region of O(k)! Here is the positivity condition from last post:

Starting with few fingers we've actually looked at a flag made of simplices: a vertex, an edge, a triangle, a tetrahedron, and so on until we reach dimension k. Doing that is called decomposition into
and it includes one region for every dimension.
We could instead look at all possible ways to combine the independent vectors from our complete graph picture and end up with some factorial number of cells called

, which is surely fine grained enough to answer questions like wether a point P is inside the positive region. It is actually so much information that fully understanding this implies as much wisdom to be gained about algebraic varieties, essentially killing the subject.

In other words: that's hopeless! But what We have been discussing so far suggests another way to triangulate (simplexify?) a polytope: we pick an initial segment, a Schubert cell like before, but we also allow cyclic shifts of our window! Postnikov calls this positroid stratification, if you're clever picking your favorite positive point you end up with matrices like these
I heard that Young tableaux are a nice thing to think of here...

Oh well, I wished I had more time. As the graph picture suggests you can get any positive Grassmannian from projecting a higher dimensional simplices to a lower-dimensional space. But to get an Amplituhedron you would project the positive Grassmannian yet again to another hyperplane...

The plan for today would have involved developing "plabic graphs" as notation for describing permutations of the vertices-on-a-circle as planar networks, which I could then relate to the logarithmic singularities of the differential operators in the dual cell complex living in physical space... all that and more in the next post. Stay tuned!

Hunting for Amplituhedra in positive Grassmannian spaces

– Let's delve into a beautiful generalization of projective geometry: into the world of Grassmannian geometry. To get an idea of the territory we'll encounter a few handful of delightful elementary concepts which can be elegantly fused to inspect polytopes inside the positive section of Grassmannians, a region which is much easier to understand than the general beast. Come along, we're starting right now:
is the space of all k-dimensional subspaces in R^n. Although other fields or manifolds might also work.

RP^(n-1) or just P^(n-1). Gr(1,n) is the space of all lines in n-dimensional space which pass through the origin. We need the origin because otherwise we don't get a subspace. Gr(1,3) is the space of all such lines in 3-space, and that one looks like a half-sphere with a twisted

Remember? Any direction in R³ can be given by a 3-vector, and any line consists of all the points we can reach by stretching that vector while maintaing its direction. Since the length of the vector doesn't really matter we get a family of which any member describes a line: an element of, or a point in Gr(1,3).

This way to denote points on RP^n is called homogeneous coordinates. Note that we can also stretch [a:b:c] by a negative factor q and still end up describing the same point. Note also that there is no point deserving the name [0:0:0] so at least one coordinate has to be nonzero.
it turns out we need two equations or vectors to describe a plane. This pattern holds and we can describe points in Gr(k,n) as a k×n matrix! For example:

Then Gr(2,3) should be the space of all planes in 3-space (containing the origin). But since every such plane can also be given by a 3-vector (its surface normal), we obtain the same space as Gr(1,3) = P². Which is a two-dimensional surface for which two coordinates seem to be enough, what's going on? Simple scaling won't rid us of the extra parameters...
, sometimes called Grassmann coordinates because it was actually
's notation for arbitrary k. It seems Graßman helped Plücker out a little because it was Plücker who found Gr(2,4): the first Grassmannian that isn't just a projective space.

Looking at our k×n matrix we can construct a square minor (matrix) of maximal dimension k by striking out the i'th column. Lets call the determinants of our minors delta Δ1 Δ2 Δ3. Remember, such a determinant gives the signed volume of a parallelpiped spanned by the vectors that ended up in our maximally sized minor.

Together with the scaling relation we recover the homogeneous coordinates for Gr(2,3). What about that smallest non-projective Gr(2,4)? It turns out that the scaling relations aren't enough to completely collapse families of coordinates pointing at the same element, we need more
Because of the scaling property we find that Δij = -Δji so we don't need both, and that means that if there were any Δjj they'd have to be zero. Playing some more you might find another relation:
You can write this one graphically as a sum of pairs of chords in a circle:
And here is the sign-flip for any k:
For more on relations like these take a look at
In the end it is not quite trivial to understand Grassmannians in full generality, but we can make things much simpler by restricting our interest to the
Gr+(k,n) which is a region or section of the full space that has the shape of a convex polytope!

The positivity condition we want is that all Plücker symbols must be positive. Well, as I said earlier, switching the indices like Δij = -Δji also flips the sign, so we need to pick a canonical order of the indices and demand their symbols to be positive. With the pyhsicist's short-hand for a determinant we might state this as:

should be positive. As is true for any determinant, if you cyclically shift or "roll" the vectors, and k is odd, it changes sign. When k is even nothing happens, such determinants are cyclically invariant.

The advantage of the positive region is that we can stop worrying about crosscaps and other weird topological features. Our first example, the real projective plane P² is completely symmetric: any of its points is equivalent to all others, and if you cut it into pieces the crosscap is gone! So the positive part of Gr(1,3) is exactly an octant of a sphere!

But there is more. We will be interested in high-dimensional Grassmannians, and that means that we will get a polytope made of of points, lines, faces, hyperfaces up to (n-k)-hypervolume. Like polyhedra the positive Grassmannians have a discrete and combinatorial structure. And as it is with platonic solids, when we understand this structure we have also understood something about the symmetries of the space they live in!
Now let's take a look at Gr+(2,4) shall we?
There are six ways to strike out two of the four columns of a 2×4 matrix, so we get six Plücker symbols.
Here, let me show you in binary which indices are mentioned in each symbol

There is a cycle of four where the ones and zeros are adjacent, and two symbols have no such pairs. It looks like an octahedron! There are two more internal faces, one is the square 1010-1100-0101-0011, the other the square 1010-0110-0101-1001, both are suspended vertically from the pair-free top and bottom vertices.
There are also four more 3-cells (volumes), I remember those been called tetrahedra, but I'm not quite sure.

This is part 1 of a series of three blog posts to explain in detail how the Amplituhedron simplifies the calculation of scattering amplitudes (Feynman diagrams and stuff). Clearly, not all non-escaping orbits come back to the origin, but do all repeating ones have to? Because we put in zero as

I decided that it shall be more fun to color the whole image based on how close the iteration gets to the zero point, and see what comes out.
Or at least, that's what I used for the brightness, hue is based on the angle of that point that got so close to zero. This makes visible another interesting structure I'll not talk about today...

With that coloring we can see a white spot at the origin, and one in the middle of every bulb. There are infinitely many bulbs attached to the boundary of the main cardioid (heart shape), in fact, there are infinitely many bulbs on any interval of that boundary.

We also get another dense but countable layer of bulbs around any bulb, and on all those bulbs and so on. Even the dendritical structures are full of them. I have no good way to traverse the whole boundary of the m-set, but we can project any point in the plane onto the part of the boundary which coincides with the large cardioid like this:
onto the unit circle, which we shift such that it touches zero, then squaring all these points gets us the points of a cardioid, which we then flip, shift, and rescale to match the one we want.

The image shows the orbit for a point on the cardioid near one of the four larger bulbs possessing five-star antennas. You can see which one, as the orbit passes through that particular bulb. It is a peculiar orbit. Contracting orbits from the inside of the mandelbrot set can feel like lattices, like stars or spirals. It is entertaining to explore the inside of the main cardioid (see puzzle 1) where the shape varies smoothly with the starting point.
I'm not talking about what's happening in the bulbs because what we see there is very similar to the simple case of the inside of the main cardioid I'm focusing on. In what way?

There's more to the Mandelbrot set than the inside of the main body, there are many filaments and even miniature copies of the main shape attached to those (they're called "minibrots"). Can we understand these features in a similar way, by looking at the orbits outside the set?

"Varies smoothly", yes, but the later points of an orbit move around much more than the initial points. Can we still differentiate the ideal orbit, the whole infinite sequence of points we can squeeze out of any starting point?

And of course there's the zero orbit, and its pendants inside the bulbs. But approaching our favorite boundary we're getting close to many of the latter. That's why our boundary orbits all kiss zero! I mean, looking at the picture, we can see that the cardioid is outlined in white...

What I find so very odd about these boundary orbits is that they seem to give a continuum of points! Of course, by construction we can only ever get Cantor sets (point sets), but in our case these seem to approximate the continuum, it is a line-filling Cantor set!

The bulbs close by seem all to contribute to the shape, smaller bulbs causing smaller wiggles, or spirals, or small, erm, 2-stars! In the end, the shapes on the boundary don't vary continuously at all!

When you get very close to the point where a bulb touches the cardioid, just between the left and the right winding clover leaf figures, you see a star. That's not an artifact of floating point arithmetic, is it? Is it approximating something?

I love the Mandelbrot set! There is so much more to tell, but this post has to end. So I'll come back and write more about it! Next: Something slightly related about solenoids and rep-tiles, and a piece about gyroids! See you soon and merry christmas!

states that we cannot combine spacetime symmetries (the Poincare group) with anything else: any additional
can only interact trivially with spacetime's
It seems the only loophole is supersymmetries, because they contain generators ('supercharges') that aren't scalars but spinors. This is the
It extends Coleman-Madula by allowing anticommutative generators in addition to the commutative ones.

In 1971 Golfand and Likhtman were the first to show that the Poincaré algebra can be extended through introduction of four anticommuting spinor generators (in four dimensions), which later became known as supercharges.
These theorems are very specific to Minkowski spacetime, neither holds for de-Sitter spacetime. Both theorems describe only unbroken symmetries.
Also note that, if only massless particles exist, Poincare symmetries are just the conformal symmetries: No matter – no problems!
For more about this stuff, see the article on super Poincare algebra here:

I like superalgebras because they're an elegant piece of mathematics. I have no qualms introducing imaginary objects, even ghost particles, or other mathematical features that are hard to interpret physically. That's because I don't care if we obtain a physical theory.

Many people seem to associate supersymmetry with a particular class of extensions of the standard model of particle physics. You see, we call the even part of a superalgebra its bosonic part, and the odd is called fermionic. That is so because the standard model already describes these particles as the even and odd part of a superalgebra...

It's just that these two cannot be modeled as parts of the same superalgebra! Or rather, they can, but then they'd come with their own superpartners. But other than in relation to these particular extensions of the standard model, supersymmetry is everywhere!
Wherever we need spin there's supersymmetry lurking somewhere! Superalgebra seems to be a natural home for spinors similar to the complex numbers containing all algebraic extensions.

1. What's latent semantic analysis? What word2vec? — A few weeks ago a friend of mine asked if I'm still in the consulting business, something about data mining.
​​​ had just written about dictionary aware improvements of word2vec based search engines. Equipped with a single important keyword, what could possibly go wrong, so I said yes...
Let's find out about semantics and search, and word embedding techniques, shall we?

2. Latent semantic analysis was pioneered in the 1980's. Or maybe it wasn't, as it is conceivable that similar techniques were used earlier by spooks to analyze heaps of text. Why does that make me think of

It combines linear algebra, vectors, and counting words. From there, clustering is the obvious next thing to do, but you can convert example texts into search terms. Or subtract one document from another to find approximate examples!

3. Latent semantic analysis starts with the 'bag of words' hypothesis: The idea is to count how often a word appears in a fragment of text. Ignoring grammar, or any other  context. We record this data in a giant matrix, columns correspond to words, and rows to fragments.
Instead of 'fragment' you could think 'document', but segmenting text into paragraphs is usually a better idea.
So, we get a huge array mostly filled with zeros, a sparse matrix. What to do with it? Read on...
4. Singular value decomposition! When you have a sparse matrix you can find a much smaller matrix that approximates the original linear transformation in a smaller space. Here's how:

An eigenvector is a direction which does not change when the matrix 'M' acts on it. The length of a vector 'v' in that direction may change, and the factor 'a' by which it does is interesting in itself, so it deserves an special name: it is an eigenvalue!
5. Our original word vectors gave a basis, and we can take the set of eigenvectors to get another basis just as good! That's nice as it will rid us of redundancies, but it gets better:
We can discard eigenvectors with small eigenvalue to find a good approximation! Somehow, the eigenvalues relate to the relevance search terms!
To compare two documents (or to find one similar to a given) just measure the angle between their vectors! "cosine similarity"
6. Linear algebra isn't too computationally challenging, but given a large matrix, performance becomes an issue. It took a while to come up with a fast algorithm, but there's a better way: word2vec!
We can use a shallow 2-layer neural network to approximate our matrix instead! You heard about tensor networks? Turns out they model precisely a stack of linear operations, just like tensors!
Cool thing is, you can insert documents incrementally! What are 'sliding bags'?
7. Remember? We started out with the bag-of-words hypothesis, discarding all context. Instead of looking at a paragraph at a time (to count words) we might look at all sequences of, say, 10 words.
See, it's like generating many intermediate documents, which would, again, blow up the necessary computations for LSA. Neural networks behave much better in this respect.
Neural (tensor) networks can be sized independently from the input. What else affects quality?

8. A semantic neural net predicts a word given its surrounding window. It's tempting to weigh the words in a window so nearby words count more than ones far away. This idea can lead to even more syntax aware extensions of word2vec.

Understanding why it works is more difficult, and much is still unclear. Usually you need a dimension between 100(!) and 1000. Weighted methods are better, but also slightly more expensive. Windows as small as 20 words give good results.
9. On improving results of semantic search, semantic indexing and clustering.
Stop words are those that occur very often and have little specialized meaning, like 'the', 'and', 'of', ... Clustering benefits greatly from removing them from the dataset.
If your text corpus comes from scanning and
'ed printed stuff you may have a problem with typos. Dictionaries can help here. There are also specialized ones for detecting spelling variants.

I was quite excited when I saw this. Changing data for Lambert's W does suprisingly little to the 'end-result' (with some high n), but it changes the combinatorics of black and white rings. the (0+i) example I gave above produces snakes!

Every complex function is mostly a geometrically rather tame, so called 'conformal' distortion of the plane. To make a picture of a distortion we have to put another picture behind it, and that's just how a phase portrait is obtained.

For every pixel, let the distortion send it elsewhere, and look up what the color of our test image is at that point. That's it! In contrast to the usual function plots we often see for real functions, this depiction is happening in reverse! Usually we keep the x-axis straight, and let the function wiggle up and down, in this case we're keeping the function fixed, and let the real and imaginary axes wobble.
Note also the color scheme, which is a simplified version[¹] of the gorgeous one

uses on his blog. The white lines are where the function has pure real value, on the black ones it returns purely imaginary values. Like the classic phase coloring it does not show the stretching involved in the distortion.

— Pictures of clouds, and of using fuzzy things to sharpen them.

is a little spacecraft that made its way to Jupiter last year, and is currently in an eccentric orbit around the giant, taking pictures and other measurements every other month. Last week, on February 2nd, it picked up a bunch of fresh impressions, which NASA put online right away, for us to play with...

Well, almost right away, they had to download them first, which took a while, and on 6th we got neatly stitched and sphere mapped pictures. Stitching is a lot of work, thanks NASA! Other than that, the material is quite raw:

The first thing to do with a new sensor image like this, is to expand the brightness of the image. Ignoring the pitch black ones, the darkest pixel started at 19/256 intensity, the brightest (ignoring some freaks at the edges) is at only 143/256.

Gimp's 'color curves' feature lets you draw a function to map each pixel's intensity to a new 'value'. Look at the histogram in that widget's background to get an idea about the number of pixels per intensity.

Fine tuning that curve will already get you to a very good result, even though Jupiter's bands vary a lot in brightness, and one could compensate by 'equalizing' first, setting the brightness to 50% everywhere.
But I like the bands in the original, as they correspond to the facts and it just feels right that way. So let's stick to it. Now for more details, how can we do that?
operation is to blur the image! You then subtract the blurred from the original, and add that difference back to the original, and voila: a subtle edge enhancement has happened.

How? Pick a row of pixels, and plot their intensity as a function graph of the x coordinate showing the pixel intensity on the y axis. Imagine that there's a sudden but small change somewhere on that function, a little jump.

Blurring our function will widen the step to a ramp or some other less steep curve. The difference between those is zero where the original function does not change suddenly, but it is positive before the original goes down, and negative afterwards.

The procedure will add these bumps to the picture, making bright pixels brighter when dark pixels are nearby and the other way around. It introduces bands around edges to make a jump larger, so we can see it more easily.

You can often tune the radius of the blurring part, or scale how much of the effect to add to your picture. I've seen unsharp-mask features allowing to scale the brightening and darkening independently, or which work with two radii for adjusting small and large scales in one go.
But If you do this by hand you're free to change the blur function in fancy ways! Try it with a directional blur!
In addition to adjusting colors and the unsharp mask, I darkened some edges to make a few of the camera artifacts less irritating. Here's my result for the full picture:

For the picture of this post I ramped up the scaling to about 5, which is quite extreme. I also didn't care to preserve the brighter parts so we can peek at what I think are seven storms in a hexagon. Too bad Juno barely managed to capture half of it. Next time, perhaps?

I find these pictures fascinating, and they have absorbed me for hours now. A pixel is on the order of 100km, and you need 11 Earth disks to span Jupiter's. Some storms look like depressions, others seem to tower up! I just wished the images had 10x their resolution!

You may have heard that root functions thrive in the complex domain and that we can only see shadows of their real life on the pale real line. Everything is much easier in their world - the Riemann sphere: Infinity is just a point like any other, conveniently located at the north-

But we're here to look at singular points, and somehow get rid of the infinity in the derivative right in front of us. Since Riemann we know how to squeeze the infinite far away onto a finite sphere, can't we do something similar here? Some sort of projection applied in reverse...
The topology of the Riemann sphere is quite different from the
: the sphere adds a point at infinity, while the

adds a line at infinity, consisting of points, one for every possible slope. It's a Moebius band glued to a disc (or to a sphere with a circular hole cut out). I'll tell you a bit more about how to do that in a minute.

Comparing a 1-complex-dimensional Riemann sphere with the 2-real-dimensional projective plane doesn't seem quite fair, but the twist isn't apparent on the (1d) real projective line, which, topologically, is just a circle.

And we need the real plane anyways to draw graphs of real functions. Graphs of complex functions can be drawn just as easily on 4d paper. What do you say? There's no 4d paper? Can I have 3d paper? Not at the moment? Rubber bands then? Fine, these wide ones will do. Let's have some fun with them in a minute.

associates to every point x in the complex plane another point y in the result space 'above' the base plane, which is also a complex plane. Above every x there's always room for any y. A function lifts the base space (the x axis/plane) along the free directions (the y axis/plane) to the target position (a curve/surface).

I hope you can see now that graphs of complex functions are 2d surfaces in 4d space! But if we don't mind self-intersections (the full picture doesn't have them) we can get away with a moderate and topologically accurate simplification,  looking at surfaces inside a simple 3-ball!

Back to the real cusp we started out with. When a function sends its graph towards minus infinity near an odd pole (even poles squarely remove all minus signs) it comes back from the opposite direction, plus infinity. That's all you need to know about how to glue a Moebius band onto a circle: every point gets connected to the opposite point on the circle.
In the complex picture we can basically extend the coordinate system to someting larger that allows us to analytically continue our picture beyond the singularity.

For example, take the polar coordinate system, which itself has a singularity at its origin, remove (a small disc at) the origin to obtain a cylinder. Voila, another such half-infinite cylinder (say, a Riemann hemisphere) fits right onto the border along which we had cut out our small disc in the first place.
What about the Moebius band, can we use one of these instead? After all, it has just a single border.
Indeed we can, and that's just what is needed to blow up cusps coming from odd powers, functions which become continuous at infinity that way. That's what we need for our example!

I've just blown up a point (yeah, yeah, a disc), grown it to a fresh new copy of the whole Riemann sphere or rather, in our case, a Moebius band! The singularity is surely gone now, isn't it? I mean, the whole place is gone, where could it possibly be?!
Calm down, blowing up our example got us a parabola. We've just

, that is keeping all the complex magic intact, stretched out the cramped space in that cusp, and after tidying the result we find that the whole is a simple parabola. Well, the real part of it, as you can't see the twist of the Moebius band when you're a mere 1-dimensional 'real' person.
But the full complex picture shows that we've just changed the topology of the base space!
Blowing up once may not be enough. When we replace the 3 by a 5 in Euler's example, blowing up will again yield a cusp, and we may need to blow up once more to smooth things out.

We have ignored branches so far, and you have to take them into account to construct a consistent picture. But that's the overview I have for you. I hope you can now imagine that a mutated topology like this might naturally embed knotted curves. And that encoded in the topology there is enough information to reconstruct the cusp!
A last bit: there are other transforms to blow up points. Ours is just a historical example that works well on Puiseux polynomials.

Breaking symmetries for fun and profit, part 1:
Hi! Join me standing on this rock (I like to call it 'Rock'), and let's toss pebbles into empty space together.

If you give one a whack sideways it might end up orbiting the rock. That's a classical setup, and the pebble's orbit will have rotational momentum, which in turn is conserved, so the rock must also gain rotational momentum in the opposite direction. The direction you throw things doesn't really matter, unless, of course, you kick something straight up.

But wait, angular momentum has nothing to do with gravity! Okay then, let's just suppose the velocity of the pebble to be much larger than the rock's escape velocity, so it won't orbit but practically go in a straight line.

The angular momentum transferred to the rock doesn't change if we disregard gravity. So, will the pebble end up spinning wildly, as to balance the rotational impulse we passed to Rock by throwing it...?

No! Angular momentum is measured with respect to some arbitrary origin, as the sideways component of the velocity vector, as seen from that origin. We're completely free to pick such a point, stationary, or even evolving according to the laws we're studying.
​​​​​​ (minutephysics) puts it, "_If the sun weren't there, earth would continue moving in a straight line, but angular momentum would still be conserved!"_
What is going on here? Conservation of angular momentum is less of a property of the objects, but rather about the space we have sketched our model in!
showed that conserved quantities and symmetries of (the field and thus phase-) space are the exact same thing!

That's very intriguing, as it shouldn't be necessary to look inside an object to determine what it's doing with respect to the environment. It should be enough to sum up the reaction mass ejected by or colliding with a rocket to calculate the action it applies, and the effect to expect (bye bye EmDrive).

In some ways the holographic principle turns that idea around to say that it shouldn't be necessary to look outside a closed... sack of space to determine its intrinsic properties... But I digress, let's keep looking at angular momentum.
Suppose you'd whirl some weight around, you'll need a string to force it in a circle (or some other force in its place). You'll notice that the string is pulling outwards, the perceived
, physicists insist, doesn't exist! The exact opposite, you pulling on the string, called centripetal force, does!

That may sound silly, but consider:In a world with only gravity you'd never feel any outward force, because the only thing that could hold a satellite in its orbit, or hold anything together for that matter, is gravity. No strings attached, all objects are either free-falling or possibly somehow on top of each other.
But that wasn't what I wanted to turn back to. It's this: What shape would a space need to possess so rotational symmetry gets broken? A simple example, perhaps?
for as many points as the surface of a 4-sphere. Or as many as two solid 3-balls, as such a pair is a model for the 4-sphere. But let's look at something even simpler:
(that's an orientation without any twist), like, have a field pointing...
. Such a directional vector field associates a direction and strength to every point in space. It's called a
All particles are now accelerated 'that way'. When the force field acts like gravitation we don't have to consider the ratio (or relation) between mass and charge. Mass
charge and all objects accelerate at the same rate. A special case we could call it 'acceleration field'.
Now, angular momentum with the axis parallel to the field vectors is still conserved, but for motions with a component orthogonal to the field it's not!
What happens? Take two initially comoving objects, that are separated by some distance along the field. That distance component will increase exponentially with time!

Or toss a pebble 'straight up', that is, radially away from Rock, so initially without angular momentum, but diagonally with nonzero components in both, the vertical / along, and the horizontal / across directions.

Given the usual formulas for angular momentum we find that a test pebble follows a curve, with angular momentum increasing for a while, until the trajectory gets dominated by the field's acceleration.
But maybe we should use a different formula for angular momentum!
What reason could there be to suggest that that can't be done?
There are of course other ways to break symmetry. A rotating planet picks a direction with its axis, it breaks symmetry!
I'm not quite out of juice here, but this post is getting too long. If you think it shouldn't end here, tell us in the comments!
Are quantum-spin numbers compatible with angular momentum? Could I, say, spin up a black hole by dropping particles into it with carefully aligned quantum spin?

message: Concerning puzzle 2: Quantum spin definitely is a type of angular momentum. It's the Noetherian conserved quantity related to rotational symmetry, and it can be exchanged with other types of angular momentum, so angular momentum as a whole is not conserved unless it is included.
Sometimes, I hear people claim that when we speak of spin as angular momentum, we are merely using a colorful metaphor drawn from a common mathematical structure. This irks me.
However, for other mathematically similar properties, such as "isospin" in nuclear physics, the disclaimer applies. Isospin is
angular momentum, though it resembles it mathematically. There is no way to exchange isospin with regular spin, or with orbital angular momentum.
​, I had no idea! So angular momentum really really must be quantized. That's still so very weird to me.
Special thanks for mentioning isospin. Of course! Why shouldn't there be other, independent quantities with rotational symmetry.

In the case of isospin, the "rotation" is not a rotation in physical space, it's in an abstract space of particle flavors. That is why isospin is fundamentally different. Similarly with "weak isospin" in the Standard Model of Particle Physics, which is much like isospin but not quite the same.
coupled, there are still enough degrees of freedom left to get independent spin structures!
It's fascinating that these things are crammed into the standard model, or rather the plenty of room its symmetries provide to accomodate examples like the ones you gave.

With isospin, the "rotational" symmetry is broken by such things as particle mass and charge terms, which act, in the abstract flavor space, rather similarly to the force field you imagine in your example. It's not actually a conserved quantity--but it's close enough to conserved that the fact is useful in deriving some things.
isospin rotation is both a gauge symmetry, and a
symmetry--thanks to everyone's friend the Higgs field. And that is a tale in itself.

- Quotients can be used in many contexts to specify a structure Q starting from large object G and a subobject S whose structure should somehow be removed from G to obtain the quotient Q=G/S. So much for the definition, but what does it mean? Read on...
We all know one kind of quotients: division. But the quotients known to topologists are much simpler!
Given a topological object, or rather the space inside, we can
points. That is: glue them together. Let's take a sphere, and identify its two poles N and S. You get something resembling a donut with a wasp's hip.
There. Your first quotient. As simple as that.

Now, let's divide something, say 6/2. Because it is easier when we know the answer beforehand, think of the dividend as a 2x3 rectangle. A triple of pairs. What gets identified here? '2' formally consists of {0,1} and each of these pairs collapses to a single cell:
What you see here in the denominator is a set of equalities, each defining a set of points. Every of these point sets collapses.
So, in our division example, we're left with just the y component:

Division of numbers is a big and complicated idea, and introducing quotients with division as first example is unfortunate, because quotients can be much simpler. It took me a long time to learn to see these simple examples!
Note: In mathematics, everything is supposed to be simple. If it appears complicated you're most probably doing it wrong!

But then, mathematicians are incredibly lazy, and you often see them writing quotients without explicit equalities. We knew that 6 secretly has a 2x3 shape, and that made it easy to find the 2's in 6 to collapse...

As the definition in the beginning says, quotients are supposed to preserve the axioms that hold for G (and possibly S), in our examples these were the group laws, in particular Q should inherit the group operation. We should be able to define it using only G's operation and the equalities.

Okay, to compute q1+q2 we can find g1 and g2 by picking a point from each of the two sets of G-points corresponding to q1 and q2. Then do G's operation to obtain a resulting g3=g1+g2 and find that in one of the point-sets. That set should be called q3=q1+q2, and we're done.

The real work is to prove that our expectations (the laws) are still satisfied by the new operation, that the result is the same no matter which representatives we pick from q1 and q2. Because every g can be found in exactly one q we don't have to worry wether we can find g3 in some q.

- Simply put, homology is a way of counting holes in a space.
So, for example, a figure 8 has two obvious holes. A figure 0 has one.
But a basic realization here is that you don't just want to count holes and get a number: there's a way to add and subtract holes, so you get an abelian group!
For the figure 8 this group is just Z^2, since you can take any integer linear combination of the obvious holes, and get a fancier kind of hole that wraps around more times.
It's actually bit more complicated than I let on: holes can have different dimensions, so a space actually has lots of homology groups, one for each dimension.
The holes in a figure 8 are declared to have dimension 1, since the 'stuff' in the 8 that wraps around the hole is a curve, and mathematicians say curves are 1-dimensional.

It later became clear that the most beautiful way to get these "groups of holes" for a space X is to form the set [X,K(Z,n)] consisting of homotopy classes of maps from X to a special space K(Z,n). This space has an n-dimensional hole in it, and nothing much else. Each hole in X gives a way to map X to K(Z,n), sending the chosen hole in X to the hole in K(Z,n).
In fact K(Z,n) is an abelian group, so [X,K(Z,n)] is a group.
You might think this is called a homology group, but no!
Because we study holes in X by maps from X to K(Z,n), we can compose a map from Y to X and a hole in X and get a hole in Y:
So, this thing [X,K(Z,n)] is contravariant: maps from Y to X turn holes in X to holes in Y.

wrote: "K has just one hole, and we map one of X's holes to it. What happens to X's other holes? Do we only map a neighbourhood of that one hole in X to K?"

No, we map all of X to K = K(A,n).  K(A,n) has a lot of stuff in it besides its hole, and that stuff is just there to make it possible to map the rest of X somewhere... and to make sure that any way to do can be deformed to any other way, as long as the hole in X gets sent to the hole in K(A,n) in the correct way.

The best example to think about is K(Z,2).  K(Z,1) is a circle, which has an obvious 1-dimensional hole, and you might naively guess that K(Z,2) is a 2-sphere, since that has an obvious 2-dimensional hole.  But that's not true!  The reason is that the 2-sphere also has a 3-dimensional hole!  There are nontrivial ways to map a 3-sphere to a 2-sphere, as discovered by Hopf sometime around the 1930s.  This came as a huge shock at first.

In fact the 2-sphere has holes of arbitrarily high dimension!  To build K(Z,2) you can start with the 2-sphere and keep attaching balls of higher and higher dimensions to fill all these holes.  The 2-sphere is CP^1, and K(Z,2), when you're done building it, is CP^infinity.  The intermediate stages of this process of hole-filling give all the spaces CP^n.

Don't let the task strain you. Don't get stuck. Strive to make it a fun experience. Read multiple times, in different situations and times of day.
You need to recognize when you're not up to the approach you're following right now. Best make it a habit to ask yourself regularily, assess what you're doing and how well it is working out, and then

Combine reading with other tasks. Do 5-10 minute intervals each, reading and cooking, or walking, or exercising, or play an instrument, or ... But avoid reading something else or getting completely distracted. Ask yourself what to do every 5 minutes!

Start by sighting the material. Don't try to understand everything, or even most of it on the first time. But do try to read out aloud new words, symbols, and formulae you don't understand yet. It'll acquaint you with the vocabulary even if you don't feel like you get anything.

Picking up language and formalisms is hard! Get yourself to "touch" these things by playing with them. Strange fonts and weird hieroglyps are just like letters, don't let this unfamiliarity numb you! Scribbling nonesense with them helps, finding spoken words does too!
Reading maths is hard. Some texts are very condensed, compressed to the point that it may take you months to understand them.

Sketch whatever you do understand. Take notes, draw doodles, play with pebbles, or talk to yourself. Use your own language, or make one up. Pick simple examples to test what you've learned. Try to write down both, what you think you understand, and what you don't think you can do: Surprise!

Complementary to that: Have questions and cherish them! Good ones will resist your attempts to answer them. Like a lighthouse they'll help you focus and notice your progress. Questions are good! You can also pester your peers or teacher with them.

Write down failed attempts, and misunderstandings, too! If talking to someone, do not hesitate to tell if you don't understand something. Real mathematicians will find that very attractive and likeable! And almost as sexy as answers...
Make sure you can decipher your notes later, but don't waste your time making them look too good. You can do that when it comes to writing up results.

When you have a rough idea what it is all about, start focusing! Try to roll up the whole thing based on what you do understand, and figure out where your current limits are. You don't have to follow the argumentative order the math is presented in your material, because this is for you. Read backwards, read other sources (try wikipedia), or find your own approach.
Look out for standard bits. What are the
? Do you understand the relevant assumptions (propositions,
), and where are they written up? What are important
(or lemmas, or corollaries, all names for proven truths).
Look twice at definitions. If written up nicely, definitions should be

should be clearly defined. In practice some of that information might be hidden, somewhere else, or just not there. It's okay to guess these details, but do write your guesses down - they might give good questions later.
Don't get frustrated. Sometimes, a tiny misunderstanding makes all your attempts crumble. Don't despair, these things can easily be debugged with a little help.

Almost all mathematically concepts are intrinsically simple. If you think it is too complicated you're probably looking at it the wrong way. When the author compressed some relation to a single letter you're often not supposed to see all the messy details behind it. It has turned into a
that is being used to explain something else.
Talk to your peers, talk to people who did or do something related. Make sure they notice where your knowledge ends, otherwise they will have a hard time helping you.

Find alternative reading material, or shorts about stuff not directly related. There is some piece out there you really want to read. Beyond the quality stuff, there are some extraordinary nice works out there. What would the grown-up's like to read?
If nothing helps, go play, and try again tomorrow. In the learning business, contemplation and sleep are work, too!

Your story might contain nouns for all objects of interests, verbs that allow to relate them in each of the important ways, or be structured in a very different way. If your language is one of the better ones, it'll allow others to reason in interesting directions you haven't thought of before.

Today I want to talk about objects called Lie Algebras, and how they relate to Lie groups.

Let's take s and t to be infinitesimals, i.e. s and t are not 0, but s^2 = t^2 = 0. Also assume st = ts and st  is not 0 (but (st)^2 = stst = stts = 0). There are a variety of issues when it comes to using infinitesimals, but we're going to ignore them for now. Everything can be replaced with exponentials and derivatives and such later, but that's a bit more unwieldy.
Let X be any n-by-n matrix. Then I + sX is also an n-by-n matrix. Note that (I + sX)^{-1} = I - sX, which is only true for any X because s is an infinitesimal.
Similarly, we can look at 1 + tY.

If we have two invertible matrices A and B, we can look at ABA^{-1}B^{-1}. This object is equal to I if and only if A and B commute (AB = BA), so this object encodes information about the group structure.
Letting A = I + sX and B = I + tY, we get
(I + sX)(I + tY)(I - sX)(I - tY) = I + st(XY - YX)

So we have that the noncommutativity of A and B is given by XY - YX, which we denote by [X, Y] and call the bracket of X and Y. Conversely, if I + sX and I + tY are both in a group, then so is I + st[X, Y].

Note that if X has trace 0, then I + sX has determinant 1, and conversely if I + sX has determinant 1 then X has trace 0. More generally, the determinant of I + sX is equal to 1 + s * tr(X), because all terms involving more than one element of X also involve s^2, and hence vanish.

So we can look at the n-by-n matrices with trace 0, denoted by sl(n), and say that these are the matrices that describe the elements of SL(n) infinitesimally close to the identity. As noted above, if X and Y are in sl(n), then so is [X, Y], which makes sl(n) into what we call a Lie algebra, corresponding to SL(n).

What about GL(n)? Well, if X is any n-by-n matrix, then I + sX has nonzero determinant. So the Lie algebra gl(n) is just all n-by-n matrices. What about SO(n)? Here we need that (I + sX)^t = I - sX. (I + sX)^t = I^t +sX^t = I + sX^t, so we need that X^t = -X. Thus X is antisymmetric as a matrix. So so(n) is the set of n-by-n antisymmetric matrices.
Like with groups, Lie algebras, i.e sets with brackets, have to satisfy a few things for all scalars c and d and all Lie algebra elements W, X, Y and Z:
1: cX + Y, [X, Y] are in the set
4: [W, [X, Y]] = [[W, X], Y] + [X, [W, Y]], called the Jacobi identity
5: [cW + X, dY + Z] = cd[W, Y] + d[X, Y] + c[W, Z] + [X, Z], called bilinearity
Conditions 3, 4 and 5 are automatically satisfied by the bracket we defined on matrices, so conditions 1 and 2 are the ones you'll need to check. Check them for sl(n), gl(n) and so(n).

Condition 4 is in my opinion the most interesting one of these. It tells us that, for instance, most Lie algebras are not associative if we use the bracket as the multiplication, because [X, [W, Y]] is not usually 0, and it's the difference between [W, [X, Y]] and [[W, X], Y]. Also, I've written it the way I have because it looks like a product rule for differentiation. Namely, if we replace [W, blah] with blah' and all other brackets with multiplication, we get (XY)' = (X')Y + X(Y'). This ties in with the idea of Lie algebra elements as infinitesimals/derivatives.

If we think of the group as a space, then the Lie algebra encodes the behavior of the multiplication on that space infinitesimally close to the identity, the way that the derivative of a function at a point encodes local behavior of that function at that point. If we think of the group as a set of linear transformations, then the Lie algebra encodes the behavior of the linear transformations that are almost but not quite the identity. So antisymmetric matrices give us rotations by infinitesimal angles.

The great thing about having a group is that we can then transport this infinitesimal behavior around the entire group by multiplying by group elements that aren't infinitesimally close to the identity. Multiplying by 1 + sX by A then gives us elements infinitesimally close to A.

So we have that the noncommutativity of A and B is given by XY - YX, which we denote by [X, Y] and call the bracket of X and Y. Conversely, if I + sX and I + tY are both in a group, then so is I + st[X, Y].

Note that if X has trace 0, then I + sX has determinant 1, and conversely if I + sX has determinant 1 then X has trace 0. More generally, the determinant of I + sX is equal to 1 + s * tr(X), because all terms involving more than one element of X also involve s^2, and hence vanish.

So we can look at the n-by-n matrices with trace 0, denoted by sl(n), and say that these are the matrices that describe the elements of SL(n) infinitesimally close to the identity. As noted above, if X and Y are in sl(n), then so is [X, Y], which makes sl(n) into what we call a Lie algebra, corresponding to SL(n).

What about GL(n)? Well, if X is any n-by-n matrix, then I + sX has nonzero determinant. So the Lie algebra gl(n) is just all n-by-n matrices. What about SO(n)? Here we need that (I + sX)^t = I - sX. (I + sX)^t = I^t +sX^t = I + sX^t, so we need that X^t = -X. Thus X is antisymmetric as a matrix. So so(n) is the set of n-by-n antisymmetric matrices.
Like with groups, Lie algebras, i.e sets with brackets, have to satisfy a few things for all scalars c and d and all Lie algebra elements W, X, Y and Z:
1: cX + Y, [X, Y] are in the set
4: [W, [X, Y]] = [[W, X], Y] + [X, [W, Y]], called the Jacobi identity
5: [cW + X, dY + Z] = cd[W, Y] + d[X, Y] + c[W, Z] + [X, Z], called bilinearity
Conditions 3, 4 and 5 are automatically satisfied by the bracket we defined on matrices, so conditions 1 and 2 are the ones you'll need to check. Check them for sl(n), gl(n) and so(n).

Condition 4 is in my opinion the most interesting one of these. It tells us that, for instance, most Lie algebras are not associative if we use the bracket as the multiplication, because [X, [W, Y]] is not usually 0, and it's the difference between [W, [X, Y]] and [[W, X], Y]. Also, I've written it the way I have because it looks like a product rule for differentiation. Namely, if we replace [W, blah] with blah' and all other brackets with multiplication, we get (XY)' = (X')Y + X(Y'). This ties in with the idea of Lie algebra elements as infinitesimals/derivatives.

If we think of the group as a space, then the Lie algebra encodes the behavior of the multiplication on that space infinitesimally close to the identity, the way that the derivative of a function at a point encodes local behavior of that function at that point. If we think of the group as a set of linear transformations, then the Lie algebra encodes the behavior of the linear transformations that are almost but not quite the identity. So antisymmetric matrices give us rotations by infinitesimal angles.

The great thing about having a group is that we can then transport this infinitesimal behavior around the entire group by multiplying by group elements that aren't infinitesimally close to the identity. Multiplying by 1 + sX by A then gives us elements infinitesimally close to A.

It is false that any group can be embedded into a GL(n). Take for example a group G which can be defined by a finite number of generators and a finite number of relations. If the group G is linear (i.e. it embeds in a linear group) then it grows either polynomially, or exponentially (This is called the Tits alternative. The growth function is defined as n goes to the number of elements which can be expressed as products of at most generators.) There exist groups which grow faster than any polynomial, but slower than any exponential, hence they can't be embedded into a linear group.

If you go to continuous groups and continuous embeddings, then of course that any GL(n) is locally compact, therefore isnough to take a continuous group which is not locally compact to have a counterexample. Moreover, even ifyou take a group which is locally compact, it still may happen that it has small subgroups, then it does not embed into a GL(n). For example the group of p-adic integers does not embed in any GL(n), which is a particular case  of the Hilbert-Smith conjecture which is true for actions by Lipschitz mappings.

If you stood in a spherical room with mirrors for walls, what would you see?  Of course you'd need a flashlight.
This picture gives an idea of what you'd see.  It's small white marble in a mirrored spheroid, as drawn by
.  You can see almost endless reflections, forming complex patterns.  These pose many fascinating puzzles!
is a sphere that has been stretched or squashed along one axis.  This is a
spheroid, meaning it's been stretched: it's about 10% taller than it is wide.   The reflections in here are more complicated than in a sphere.

The pattern is made of reflections of the little white marble you can see on the right hand side. To the slightly bluish mirror it appears pure white, but I have shaded the unreflected marble afterwards to make it easier to identify.

More precisely, the marble is a sphere, with radius a tenth that of the equatorial circle of the spheroid, and touching it there from the inside. I’ve placed it 90° away from one of the two ‘straight’ positions to make the image less symmetric and more interesting.

The idea behind the marble was that we could pick a point and highlight all rays coming close to it. But the presence of the marble changes things: since it extends into the spheroid, it will catch high flying rays that might not have gotten reflected in the vicinity of our chosen point. Coloring a patch of the spheroid’s surface, or punching a hole in it, would not have produced some rather beautiful artifacts you see here.

That large, wavy, most bright reflection to the left, and all the similar ones, would resolve to a number of separate elongated images of our spot. And the smaller blots further inside, the biggest one looking like two intersecting elliptic discs, would look more like a single one. And the marble-thick, brighter appearing region all around the rim.

Aside from that, the marble works like a flashlight. Think of the pattern as a fixed, static thing, produced by all possible rays bouncing within the ellipsoid. Moving the flashlight will illuminate different parts of it. Some points will be especially hard to illuminate. Two of them are the foci of the prolate spheroid: they’re the the dark points that appear to attract reflections that can never reach them, just above and below the center.

has been writing on the various groups like SO(3) and spin(3).  I wish i understood them like i do rotations in 3d and 4d.  So here is the rotation space in 4D.

A phase space is a representation where every point in the space represents a different state of something.  The phase space of a spinning disk in 2D, might be represented by a number-line, where 0 means still, a plus intensity means it's spinning anti-clockwise, and a minus intensity means that it is spinning clockwise.  One ought note that in the real world, things spin clockwise, and in mathematics, they spin anticlockwise.

The phase space in three dimensions is much the same.  A sphere can spin on its equator, and one can find its "north pole", by placing the right hand, so that the rotation emerges from in the direction of the fingers: The thumb points to the north.  Looking down from the north, one sees the fingers curl in an anticlockwise direction.

The phase space of 3D, then corresponds to the direction of the north pole, and the radius corresponds to intensity.  One can see that reversing the rotation, without changing the axis, will swap the north and south pole, that is, give a negative direction.

In four dimensions, one can have two orthogonal rotations.  A set of rotations in say, the w-x space, still allows a second rotation in the y-z space.  "Wheel" rotation in the y-z space is not intended to rotate the cabin of the vehicle (y-z is forward+height), so one would prefer w-x to be still.  Planetary rotation tends to equalise energy in the different modes, so w-x and y-z would become equal in size.  But the two ratios are not linked in either case.
This is less clear, because 4D rotation is not something one runs across in normal life.  But it is relatively easy to construct if you know some ideas, like 'complex numbers'.

The geometry CE2 is 'complex-euclidean 2D'.  In essence, it's the ordinary x-y plane, but each axis is home to complex numbers.  So it's really 4D.  The equation for a straight line is, "y=ax+b".  We want it to pass through (0,0), so b=0.  We get y=ax.  We can multiply both sides by 'w', to give yw = awx.  The equation y=ax exists for every x,y.

The equation "w = cis(vt)" represents a rotation around the origin at the speed of v, giving a cycle over a period.  Specifically, one notes that cis(vt) = cis(vt+k), where k represents a circle.  Because we multiply this number on both sides of "y=ax", the point (x,y), belongs to a trace (wx,wy) there is a separate trace for every complex number.
This set of traces cross a 4-sphere to give a series of equidistant lines, which are not coplanar.  These are 'clifford parallels', and the rotation described is a 'clifford rotation'.

We now turn this into a sphere.  Put a unit-sphere, so its diameter runs from (0,0,0) to (0,0,1).  The points of the complex plane are now mapped onto this sphere, where the ray from the point (Re,Im,0) to (0,0,1) crosses the sphere.  Opposite points of this sphere represent orthogonal rotations, that is, the opposites place a and -1/a opposite each other for all a.

This sphere forms the basis of a radial system of 'clifford rotations' that are parallel to each other.  Clifford rotations come when the wx and yz speeds are equal, but there are left and right cliffords, where wx=yz and wx = -yz.

Every great arrow (a great circle + direction), belongs to a left and right clifford rotation, and given a set of (say) left rotations, any great arrow belongs to a right set to a single great arrow of the left set.

The full expansion of the four-dimensional rotations, then is (L,R) where L and R are perpendicular spheres in six dimensions.  The great arrows perpendicular to l,r are -l,r and l,-r.  The reversal is then -l,-r.  When we put eg r=0, we see that -l is given as part of the sphere that contains +l, but what happens is that the L axis is actually like the X axis, contains variations on R (as the X axis contains different values of Y).  The reversal of a rotation is a completely different set of parallels.

Those of ye familiar with the art of quarterions, would understand A = l.Z.r  where Z is the initial state, and A is the current state, as l and r are orthogonal clifford rotations, happen separately.

In four dimensions, the space of great arrows is that where the orthogonal rotation is zero, ie when l=r (in size).  This projects onto six dimensions as a terix (4-cloth) formed by the prism-product of two sphere-surfaces.  The opposite points l,r and -l,-r represent the same circle, pointing in orthogonal directions.
We now can see that the various rotations of the [3,3,5] contain among other things:
30 order four clifford rotations in L,0 and 0,R, being vertices of o3x5o, (ID)
20 order six clifford rotations in L,0 and 0,R, being vertices of x3o5o  (I)
12 order ten clifford rotations in L,0 and 0,R, being vertices of o3o5x (D)
900 order two wheel rotations, being ID*ID
400 order three wheel rotations, being D*D
144 order five wheel rotations, being I*I
There are other orders of rotation, such as where y=2x.  These form an array of points that form eg the stripe containing a vertex of an ID in one axis by an ID in the other.

"But the catch is that Spin(3) double covers S³." No, they're the same, they double cover RP^3.

I think the easiest way to think about this particular double cover is to start with the quaternions (R^4), look at the unit sphere therein (S^3), and have that act by conjugation on the purely imaginary quaternions (R^3). There's your map S^3 -> SO(pure imaginary quaternions). This group homomorphism kills exactly the center, which is +/-1. So there's the double covering.

's remarks: the only double cover of S³ is the trivial double cover consisting of two separate sheets, since S³ is simply connected.  The only double cover of a simply connected space is the disconnected one.  But Spin(3) is connected.

I would like to correct a misconception here: Grothendieck topology is a set of axioms that define covers on a category. In fact, on a single category, there may be several Grothendieck topologies. For example on the category of algebraic manifolds, one can define the Zariski topology, the etale topology, the FPPQ-topology, etc. Roughly, what this means is how to label an object as "open" subsets of another.

The Zariski topology is a specific type of topology that one can put on algebraic manifolds. Since every algebraic manifold is obtained by "gluing" together affine algebraic manifolds, the topology is uniquely defined by specifying what open subsets of affine algebraic manifolds are; on affine manifolds the topology is given by the requirement that closed sets are of the form V(I) where I is an ideal, and V(I) is the set of PRIME ideals containing I.

I have been thinking very hard about what would be a good text to learn algebraic geometry from. The unfortunate thing is the the subject is built on top of commutative algebra, and certainly I would recommend learning a little bit of differential geometry first. It seems that you know a bit about commutative algebra already, so if you can get your hands on Robin Hartshorne's "Algebraic Geometry", it's an "industry standard". The book itself is pretty complete, and it is a very well distillation of Grothendieck's four volume work that revolutionized the language and methodology of the subject: Éléments de géométrie algébrique I - IV (Elements of Algebraic Geometry). The entire collection of EGA can be found free on the site
; the thing is, EGA I - IV are in French, and it's quite long.

Regarding the subject of Grothendieck pretopology and topology, the original work is, I believe, developed by Verdier, Michael Artin and Grothendieck in Séminaire de Géométrie Algébrique du Bois Marie (SGA 4). Once again, this is in French, and you would have to spend some money. There is an English version, which also costs money, by Gunther Tamme, and has a more expanded (not always good) exposition on the subject of Grothendieck topos theory. The title is "Introduction to Étale Cohomology."

I guess it is worthwhile to point out that there is a free "encyclopaedia" of algebraic geometry, called the Stacks Project, and it is VERY complete. You might have heard about Λ under the name wedge product. It's the operator of the exterior algebra - also known as... Grassmann algebra! And it is anticommutative and what that means i just explained.

Usually, in quantum field theory the Grassmann variable "dimensions" correspond to a "field strength" rather than a physical dimensions.

In other words, just as the photon field has a classical limit of a field with ordinary real number values (the electric and magnetic fields, or the scalar and vector potentials if you like), an electron field would have a "classical limit" that is a field with Grassmann-variable values. In a Young diagram each row has less placeholder squares than the previous. To get a Young tableau we start with a n-square Young diagram and place the numbers from 1 to n into the squares in a particular way: If you step from a given square tor the right or down, the number there has to be bigger than the one in the original box.

Sometimes the top left corner gets the biggest number and right/down has to decrease which, of course, yields the same structure. You can flip a Young diagram along the diagonal to obtain another, usually a different one. And by the way, the french like it upside down.
Alfred Young first used these in 1900 and i'll be trying to give you an idea what for. First we need some basics:

is a way to describe symmetries. If you can reverse it and have some identity or zero move you can safely utilize all of group theory. Examples are "addition and zero", "rotations or reflections and the identity", all ways to put a cube in a box, and many many more. If you get finitely many elements the group is called discrete.

S_n (there's one for each natual number n) consists of all possible ways to order the numbers from 1 to n. It is the most general discrete group family and each and every discrete group is present as a subgroup of S_n for some n.

is a model for some structure inside another structure. Like the above paragraph says, every discrete group has a representation in some symmetric group. I hope now you can understand the following from wikipedia:

Young diagrams are in one-to-one correspondence with irreducible representations of the symmetric group over the complex numbers. [...] Many facts about a representation can be deduced from the corresponding diagram.

I'm not going to explain complex numbers here but let me say this: They behave very much like numbers but are 2-dimensional, good at rotation and just beautiful. The above tells us we can find the S_n inside the complex number plane and for each way to do that there is a Young diagram to name it. Further they say:

Young diagrams also parametrize the irreducible polynomial representations of the general linear group GLn (when they have at most n nonempty rows), or the irreducible representations of the special linear group SLn (when they have at most n − 1 nonempty rows), or the irreducible complex representations of the special unitary group SUn (again when they have at most n − 1 nonempty rows).

GL_n is also a group family and again the most general of it's kind and SL_n or SU_n are subgroups of these and are also pretty general beasts. Or to put it differently, much of GL_n's structure is also to be found in SL_n or SU_n.
John Armstrong did a course on representation theory and here's his notes where he writes about Young tableaux:

One popular extension is this: Given a Young tableau, let's allow moving the numbers such that they stay in their respective row and still follow the rules. So we're allowed to change the order horizontally but not vertically. This way you can identify a familiy of tableaux by looking at one member and see where you can go from there. That family is then called a Tabloid.

Last time we saw a way to "simplify" a Klein bottle by unfolding it into a square. The figure eight graph B below can be interpreted as an even simpler picture, this time for a two-holed torus. It says that, given a starting point a, there are two loops wich cannot be shrunk to a point.

Just above there is a different but, in a special way, similar graph X. It has two vertices and four edges. Between those graphs we have an arrow p representing a projection from the upper to the lower graph. Here, two pairs of edges in X are mapped to the ones with the same label in B, the vertices x and x' both go to a.

Funny thing is, that arrow points from the complicated X to the simple B, yet we speak of B as generating X. This is because given some X and B, projections are usually easy to describe (and to think of). Another funny thing is that the fundamental group of X is considered a subgroup of B, again just the other way around than one might have expected. Here's why:

The fundamental group describes all possible (nontrivial or "unshrinkable") paths we can have on some topological surface. So winding twice around a handle is different from winding around once. The fundamental group of B contains elements like aaa, (-b)ab(-a)bb, or any other word consisting of a, b and their negatives.

To study topological spaces, we usually pick a starting point (mostly for conveniece). Let's pick x to study X. The resulting fundamental group is built of aa, bb, and ab (because we have to get back after any single letter) and that's less than the set of all words, as allowed for the space B.

A chain complex is a notation for a list of functions which can be nested: f(g(x)) Z -- g --> X -- f --> Y. I learned about chain complexes from Allen Hatchers "Algebraic Topology" (see below for a link) and will give you the original approach as it illustrates the most popular use of chain complexes. It goes like this:
Given a triangulation of a topological surface, we'd like to write down how surfaces are attached to edges and edges are attached to vertices. (generally, how n-cells are attached to (n-1)-cells)

This is done in a formal sum. That means it is more of a data holding structure than an actual numerical sum. But we do allow sum arthmetics so we can simplify some stuff. It's pretty much like a sum over opaque variables with the variables being names for vertices. Now we can compute a polynomial over (k-1)-cell names (a list of vertices) corresponding to a k-cell.

A short exact sequence is just a chain complex telling us f(g(z)) = 0. It is often stated as im(g) \subset ker(f), that means the output of g is a subset of those inputs of f which give zero. This is to be understood as a normalized representation for a fibration. A very simple example:

Let's fibrate a 2d plane (named Z): Let g project any point down to the x-axis, and f project to the y axis. Then f(g(x)) will be zero (the origin) for any x. Now what is im(g) / ker(f)? It is the x-axis, and each point corresponds to a fiber (a vertical line in this example), that is the points which get projected there by g.
Two more things: The zero in the following sequence is a symbol to denote a constant and in this context just means all of Z.
0 --> Z -- g --> X -- f --> Y forces g to be injective.
On the other hand, the zero on the right here really means zero:
Z -- g --> X -- f --> Y --> 0 forces f to be surjective so this one:
is a notation which shows the components of some h(x) = ker(f) / im(g). Given an h we'd like to understand we have to find f and g.  In this context g and f are often called "cycle" and "boundary".

Venn diagrams have been popular to teach elementary set theory so you probably have seen one in school. One for order n shows all 2^n intersection sets. So all Venn diagrams of order n describe the same structure. Wikipedia has images up to order 6, some suggested by Venn himself:

Henderson proved in 1963 that you can find symmetric Venn diagrams of order n only if n is a prime number. Here's a beautiful one for order 11 which has been found only recently by Khalegh Mamakani und Frank Ruskey:
An Euler diagram is similar but only shows the subsets one is interested in. By leaving the uninteresting parts out one can highlight some subsets and interpret these as a boolean formula (with AND).

Now to get a spidergramm, add dots connected by lines to indicate disjunction (OR). If you place multiple spiders you get multiple formulas. Since you can also mark the outside of any set (using multiple points if necessary) you can construct negations (NOT), too.
